#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=THE ODDS AND ENDS

#Text=Of Doctor Walker 's sensational escape that night to South America , of the recovery of over a million dollars in cash and securities in the safe from the chimney room -- the papers have kept the public well informed .
#Text=Of my share in discovering the secret chamber they have been singularly silent .
#Text=The inner history has never been told .

#Text=Mr. Jamieson got all kinds of credit , and some of it he deserved , but if Jack Bailey , as Alex , had not traced Halsey and insisted on the disinterring of Paul Armstrong 's casket , if he had not suspected the truth from the start , where would the detective have been ?

#Text=When Halsey learned the truth , he insisted on going the next morning , weak as he was , to Louise , and by night she was at Sunnyside , under Gertrude 's particular care , while her mother had gone to Barbara Fitzhugh 's .
#Text=What Halsey said to Mrs. Armstrong I never knew , but that he was considerate and chivalrous I feel confident .
#Text=It was Halsey 's way always with women .
#Text=He and Louise had no conversation together until that night .

#Text=Gertrude and Alex -- I mean Jack -- had gone for a walk , although it was nine o'clock , and anybody but a pair of young geese would have known that dew was falling , and that it is next to impossible to get rid of a summer cold .
#Text=At half after nine , growing weary of my own company , I went downstairs to find the young people .
#Text=At the door of the living-room I paused .
#Text=Gertrude and Jack had returned and were there , sitting together on a divan , with only one lamp lighted .
#Text=They did not see or hear me , and I beat a hasty retreat to the library .
#Text=But here again I was driven back .
#Text=Louise was sitting in a deep chair , looking the happiest I had ever seen her , with Halsey on the arm of the chair , holding her close .
#Text=It was no place for an elderly spinster .
#Text=I retired to my upstairs sitting-room and got out Eliza Klinefelter 's lavender slippers .
#Text=Ah , well , the foster motherhood would soon have to be put away in camphor again .
#Text=The next day , by degrees , I got the whole story .
#Text=Paul Armstrong had a besetting evil -- the love of money .
#Text=Common enough , but he loved money , not for what it would buy , but for its own sake .

#Text=An examination of the books showed no irregularities in the past year since John had been cashier , but before that , in the time of Anderson , the old cashier , who had died , much strange juggling had been done with the records .
#Text=The railroad in New Mexico had apparently drained the banker 's private fortune , and he determined to retrieve it by one stroke .
#Text=This was nothing less than the looting of the bank 's securities , turning them into money , and making his escape .
#Text=But the law has long arms .
#Text=Paul Armstrong evidently studied the situation carefully .
#Text=Just as the only good Indian is a dead Indian , so the only safe defaulter is a dead defaulter .
#Text=He decided to die , to all appearances , and when the hue and cry subsided , he would be able to enjoy his money almost anywhere he wished .
#Text=The first necessity was an accomplice .
#Text=The connivance of Doctor Walker was suggested by his love for Louise .
#Text=The man was unscrupulous , and with the girl as a bait , Paul Armstrong soon had him fast .

#Text=The plan was apparently the acme of simplicity : a small town in the west , an attack of heart disease , a body from a medical college dissecting-room shipped in a trunk to Doctor Walker by a colleague in San Francisco , and palmed off for the supposed dead banker .
#Text=What was simpler ?
#Text=The woman , Nina Carrington , was the cog that slipped .
#Text=What she only suspected , what she really knew , we never learned .
#Text=She was a chambermaid in the hotel at C -- , and it was evidently her intention to blackmail Doctor Walker .
#Text=His position at that time was uncomfortable : to pay the woman to keep quiet would be confession .
#Text=He denied the whole thing , and she went to Halsey .
#Text=It was this that had taken Halsey to the doctor the night he disappeared .
#Text=He accused the doctor of the deception , and , crossing the lawn , had said something cruel to Louise .
#Text=Then , furious at her apparent connivance , he had started for the station .
#Text=Doctor Walker and Paul Armstrong -- the latter still lame where I had shot him -- hurried across to the embankment , certain only of one thing .
#Text=Halsey must not tell the detective what he suspected until the money had been removed from the chimney-room .
#Text=They stepped into the road in front of the car to stop it , and fate played into their hands .
#Text=The car struck the train , and they had only to dispose of the unconscious figure in the road .
#Text=This they did as I have told .
#Text=For three days Halsey lay in the box car , tied hand and foot , suffering tortures of thirst , delirious at times , and discovered by a tramp at Johnsville only in time to save his life .
#Text=To go back to Paul Armstrong .
#Text=At the last moment his plans had been frustrated .
#Text=Sunnyside , with its hoard in the chimney-room , had been rented without his knowledge !
#Text=Attempts to dislodge me having failed , he was driven to breaking into his own house .
#Text=The ladder in the chute , the burning of the stable and the entrance through the card-room window -- all were in the course of a desperate attempt to get into the chimney-room .
